verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: The phrase 'the word of the LORD came' introduces a prophetic message directly from God, emphasizing divine authority behind Ezekiel’s words (see also Jer. 1:2).

verses.text: Son of man, set your face toward the mountains of Israel and prophesy against them.
verses.comment: 'Son of man' is a title God uses for Ezekiel, highlighting his humanity before God (compare Dan. 7:13 for messianic usage). The command to speak against the 'mountains' addresses the high places where idolatry flourished.

verses.text: Say: 'Mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord GOD. This is what the Lord GOD says to the mountains and the hills, to the ravines and the valleys: I am about to bring a sword against you, and I will destroy your high places.'
verses.comment: The address to 'mountains, hills, ravines, and valleys' shows God’s judgment covers the whole land. The ‘high places’ were sites of idolatrous worship (see Lev. 26:30). God’s holiness requires the destruction of impurity, a principle still affirmed in the cleansing nature of worship.

verses.text: Your altars will be laid waste, your incense altars shattered. I will cast down your slain before your idols.
verses.comment: God’s judgment includes the destruction of objects of false worship, underscoring the call to true, pure worship (see 2 Kings 23:14). This reflects the seriousness of idolatry which disrupts right relationship with God.

verses.text: I will lay the dead bodies of the people of Israel before their idols, and scatter your bones around your altars.
verses.comment: The desecration of human remains in judgment, especially near idols, would have been seen as deeply shameful. This shows the gravity of rejecting God. It also anticipates the need for a reverent approach to sacred realities, which develops further in Christian worship.

verses.text: In all your dwelling places, the cities will be laid waste, and the high places will be made desolate, so that your altars will be broken and brought to ruin, your idols destroyed and blotted out, your incense altars cut down, and your works wiped out.
verses.comment: The universal scope of the destruction emphasizes God’s justice. The total erasure of idols foreshadows the call to exclusive devotion which culminates in Christian life (see Lev. 26:31).

verses.text: The slain will fall among you, and you shall know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: The repeated phrase 'you shall know that I am the LORD' underlines God’s desire for His people to recognize His sovereignty. Throughout Scripture, knowledge of God’s character is bound to experiencing both His justice and mercy.

verses.text: Yet I will leave a remnant, so that some of you may escape the sword among the nations when you are scattered through the countries.
verses.comment: God’s preservation of a remnant is a theme throughout the Bible (see Isa. 10:20-22; Rom. 11:5). This foreshadows the idea of a faithful community set apart, continuing God’s promises through generations, an undercurrent in Christian ecclesiology.

verses.text: Then those of you who escape will remember Me among the nations where they are taken captive, how I was grieved by their adulterous hearts, which turned away from Me, and by their eyes, which lusted after their idols. They will loathe themselves for the evil they have committed and for all their abominations.
verses.comment: Here we see repentance and self-loathing for sin (cf. Ps. 51:3-4), a central aspect of reconciliation with God. This introspection is essential for true worship, leading to restoration and new life—a pattern of contrition and renewal that underlies faithful living.

verses.text: And they shall know that I am the LORD and that I did not threaten in vain to bring this disaster upon them.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness includes not only mercy but reliability in judgment (see Num. 23:19). God’s warnings are real, prompting us to live lives of ongoing faithfulness and constant return to Him.

verses.text: This is what the Lord GOD says: Clap your hands and stamp your feet and cry out, 'Alas, because of all the evil abominations of the house of Israel!' For they will fall by sword, famine, and plague.
verses.comment: The physical acts (clapping, stamping) express sorrow and emphasis for judgment pronounced. Sword, famine, and plague are recurrent judgments throughout Israelite history and serve as reminders of the severe consequences of turning from God.

verses.text: He who is far away will die by the plague; he who is near will fall by the sword; and he who remains and is spared will die by famine. Thus I will spend My wrath upon them.
verses.comment: The threefold punishment shows total judgment—wherever Israel tries to escape, God’s justice reaches them. The phrase 'spend My wrath' points to the reality of divine justice, which is always perfectly measured and purposeful.

verses.text: You will know that I am the LORD when their slain lie among their idols around their altars, on every high hill, on all the mountaintops, under every green tree and every leafy oak—the places where they offered fragrant incense to all their idols.
verses.comment: False worship under every 'green tree and leafy oak' echoes the language used for idol worship in Israel (see 1 Kings 14:23). The result is the exposure of the futility of false worship compared to authentic devotion.

verses.text: I will stretch out My hand against them and make the land desolate and utterly waste, from the wilderness to Diblah, wherever they live. Then they shall know that I am the LORD.'
verses.comment: God’s 'outstretched hand' signifies power and judgment (see Ex. 7:5). The total desolation from the wilderness to Diblah indicates complete judgment, aimed at restoring proper acknowledgment of God. The repeated refrain 'they shall know that I am the LORD' moves toward the restoration of true worship, a foretaste of the ultimate unity in faith God desires for His people.
